text: Hi all. I've been running a horse racing strategy pre-off. It's placed ~1000 bets over almost as many markets at a healthy edge against sp, and had been remarkably consistent. However, over the last three days the strategy hasn't taken any value at all. Although in total the strategy is still ahead, this 'correction' has cost about 10% of total expected value. I'm concerned that I have fallen into the trap of 'it looks like it works for a month then blows up in your face'. I'm not really sure what my question is but I'm curious about other people's experiences in similar situations. I suppose I will have to wait and see if the strategy resumes positive returns.

elements.text: Hi all. I've been running a horse racing strategy pre-off. It's placed ~1000 bets over almost as many markets at a healthy edge against sp, and had been remarkably consistent. I'm concerned that I have fallen into the trap of 'it looks like it works for a month then blows up in your face'. I'm not really sure what my question is but I'm curious about other people's experiences in similar situations. I suppose I will have to wait and see if the strategy resumes positive returns.

text: Happens to me all the time. I just close my eyes and hold on.

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon
user_profile.name: fcmisc

elements.text: Happens to me all the time. I just close my eyes and hold on.

text: That's reassuring to hear. I am doing my best to hold on - finding it harder than I thought I would.

elements.text: That's reassuring to hear. I am doing my best to hold on - finding it harder than I thought I would.

text: I'm not one of the top guys here. So maybe my advice won't be the best. But I tend to bet very small relative to my bank and have several parameterizations of similar models, so it is quite rare to have downturns that significantly impact my overall PnL.

user_profile.real_name: Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon Jon

text: When I first started and was concerned about my strategy's performance, I'd just buy more backtest data :sweat_smile:. Can never have too much data

text: That's interesting, thanks. I will have a look at potentially running variations on a theme to reduce the effect of this kind of downturn in the future

text: That's not a bad idea. I have backtested over approximately 6000 recorded markets so I'm not sure whether I feel that further backtesting would change my opinion of the strategy or not to be honest, unless I get my hands on enough data to make a sensible comparison

elements.text: That's not a bad idea. I have backtested over approximately 6000 recorded markets so I'm not sure whether I feel that further backtesting would change my opinion of the strategy or not to be honest, unless I get my hands on enough data to make a sensible comparison

text: If you have that big a backtest data set then surely you can tell whether a downturn of this size is to be expected?

elements.text: If you have that big a backtest data set then surely you can tell whether a downturn of this size is to be expected?

text: Moderate ups and downs are nothing to worry about, but I'm curious as to what you mean that you've lost 10% of your 'expected value'...? Do you just mean your profit? If you mean something other than profit then how much of your profit have you lost?

elements.text: Moderate ups and downs are nothing to worry about, but I'm curious as to what you mean that you've lost 10% of your 'expected value'...? Do you just mean your profit? If you mean something other than profit then how much of your profit have you lost?

text: You're right, I should go through the data with a keener eye and work out if anything comparable shows up. It's been such a marked change from having value to not that I have found most surprising.

elements.text: You're right, I should go through the data with a keener eye and work out if anything comparable shows up. It's been such a marked change from having value to not that I have found most surprising.

text: ....and how do you know it hasn't taken any value? Your last few days might have been full of amazing value bets that just didn't win.

elements.text: ....and how do you know it hasn't taken any value? Your last few days might have been full of amazing value bets that just didn't win.

text: Assuming you haven't changed your strategy it doesn't really make sense to say that your bets before had value and your recent ones don't.

elements.text: Assuming you haven't changed your strategy it doesn't really make sense to say that your bets before had value and your recent ones don't.

text: I had this car crash a few weeks ago.

elements.text: Goodness me. Laying at long odds?

text: When I say lost 10% of expected value I mean 10% of the total value since strategy start calculated as ((price_matched / sp) -1) * matched_size. I have been closing at SP since I am relatively new so my loss in profit is the same 10% of total. When I say that the strategy hasn't taken value I mean in comparison to SP it has been behind, whereas before it was ahead. The last 150 bets have been 25% worse against sp than the preceding 1000

text: Ok so it's going to take a few thousand markets for that to shake out. To calculate a proper number you'd need to know your edge and you'd need better maths than me, but finger in the wind if you have a normal-ish edge it's going to be 5-10,000 or so real results before you have a reasonable idea where you're at with it.

elements.text: Ok so it's going to take a few thousand markets for that to shake out. text: What am I saying you don't need maths you can just MC it. It won't make any difference though you'll be waiting it out either way.

text: Yes, you're right, nothing to be done but wait and see, although I might take a look at a Monte Carlo simulation. Being at higher average odds is hindering in that you have to wait longer to see what's really happening I suppose. Thank you for your input

text: Yes it's a problem - well you've got 6 months to a year to wait so you have time to develop something more mid-market. Maybe see if you can extract the critical bit of insight that (you hope) makes this work and apply it to some more moderate odds bets. Bet at 1.5 to 3 and you'll never have to wait more than a month.

text: It had been thoroughly analysed and then backtested before going live, so I was pretty confident that it was a solid strategy and the first 20k of bets rather backed that up. Couldn't see anything in the market that had changed fundamentally, so kept the faith that it was just a bad run, and it's back doing what I would generally expect it to do.

text: Can't give concrete advice cos I don't know exactly what you're doing but is there a 2nd way to measure your performance? Simplistic example would be backing at fractionally better than SP, the gods of random could give you nightmares but you know your theoretical returns are sound and given enough time you'll catch up. Is your net position at the off looking good even though the actual return isn't?

elements.text: Can't give concrete advice cos I don't know exactly what you're doing but is there a 2nd way to measure your performance? Simplistic example would be backing at fractionally better than SP, the gods of random could give you nightmares but you know your theoretical returns are sound and given enough time you'll catch up. Is your net position at the off looking good even though the actual return isn't?

text: ... And of course a tiny edge will only take a tiny change to wreck it, do you feel there's enough leeway to withstand a reasonable degree of fluctuation?

elements.text: ... And of course a tiny edge will only take a tiny change to wreck it, do you feel there's enough leeway to withstand a reasonable degree of fluctuation?

text:
<@U01LD279D16> my MC simulation will give you basic stats, P&L graphs, ROI, etc but more importantly, it'll tell you how your strategy fairs compared to picking random runners. Given that the markets are generally efficient over a large sample, then picking at random should be roughly = 0EV pre-commission. It's very basic, but does the job it was intended for. <@UQL0QDEKA> loves it, if you hadn't guessed already. :grinning:
It just needs to be pointed at a BetHistory.csv file of settled bets, which you can download from your Betfair account.

loves it, if you hadn't guessed already.

text: Not sure if that's directed at me Shaun but if it was: overall my position against sp is good, and has been very consistent. Last few days haven't been good against sp, and that has been my concern. I think it's too early to tell what will happen longer term but it's good to hear that some fluctuation is to be expected. My edge on the whole has withstood the variation so far, so I can only wait and see, although I will go back through my backtests more thoroughly to see what kind of variability in edge they saw. (Sorry if your comments weren't directed at me)

text: It was <@U01LD279D16> (i think :slightly_smiling_face:)..but I'm not sure I said much you probably didn't already know.   The trouble with charts is that they can be like fractals, you never quite know what part you're looking at and at what zoom level. Even grim times lived in real-time can be not much more than a ripple after a year or two.  I once saw an interview with a quant, and worked with a few too back in another life, strategy death despite being the subject of plenty of research is very much a finger in the wind job, and that inexplicable 'feel' you get from experience. Taking on a comment from <@UGV299K6H> and my own limitted experience, they tend to fade rather than do an about turn so maybe that's just a bit of random weirdness. Good luck with it, no easy anwsers that I know of.
